Award.AwardTitle: Planning Project for the STEM Center for Research and Development - Increasing Minority Students in STEM Disciplines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities -Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) provides support to design, implement, and assess strategies that can lead to comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at the University of the District of Columbia seeks to establish the foundation for a "STEM Center for Research and Development - Increasing Minority Students in STEM Disciplines". The goals of the project are: to provide STEM students with information and active support designed to retain them and prepare them for graduate school or the workforce; and to provide faculty with support that will expand their teaching and research skills so that they will be better prepared to impart knowledge and assist in the development of students' skills as they forge successful mentor/mentee relationships.

Activities that are part of this project are: support for students in such areas as study skills, academic scoping skills, graduate school and fellowship application preparation, research opportunities during the academic year, as well as summer internships; one-year mini-grants to faculty members to give them the support needed to initiate and advance research and curricular reforms, train students, and promote professional development. The project will be guided by an on-going evaluation and by external and internal steering committees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Planning Project for the STEM Center for
Research and Development – Increasing Minority Students in STEM Disciplines



The University of the District of Columbia
(UDC), the Nation’s only Urban Land-Grant Institution, was awarded a
NSF/HBCU-UP Planning Project for the STEM Center for Research and Development -
Increasing Minority Students in STEM Disciplines (HRD 1531014) on September 1,
2015. We present the progress or our efforts to enhance the effectiveness of
the Center by establishing a series of innovative activities that will be
implemented in the new program. The goal of the program was to provide STEM
students with information and active support designed to highlight learning as
an active and ongoing process and enrichment as a complement to heighten ones
academic performance beyond his/her current level of achievement; and 2) to
provide faculty with activities that will expand their teaching and research
skills so they will be better prepared to impart knowledge and assist in the
development of students’ skills as they forge successful mentor/mentee
relationships and productive collaborations.



Intellectual Merit: The Center
was designed to 1) stimulate student intellectual ambition, inspiration, and
enthusiasm to complete the STEM degree, 2) increase the research capability of
STEM faculty, and 3) provide innovative support activities that complement
student learning and faculty enhancement. The Center built upon the successful
activities implemented during the first and second HBCU-UP cycles and
introduced new activities that enhance student enrichment and faculty
development. In order to enhance student learning and teacher effectiveness, we
developed a: 1) multi-tiered mentoring system to increase the likelihood that
students will

complete their undergraduate STEM degree and for faculty to improve their teaching
skills, 2) created an active Learning Community of Scholars that
encouraged a shared determination to reach a common goal. 3) offered
distinguished lectures where guest lecturers presented their research, 4)
provided tutoring to assist students in successfully completing their course
work, 5) established the graduate record examination (GRE) preparation workshop
to enhance GRE performance, 6) provided undergraduate research for students to
conduct research with a research mentor, 7) established an Academic Advancement
Partnership (AAP) to create interactions between students and graduate
institutions, 8) provided opportunities for students and faculty to participate
in the Advance Research Techniques Corp (ARTC) Workshop for students to learn
techniques and faculty to improve their teaching skills, and 9) provided
opportunities for faculty to participate in collaborative research to increase
their research capabilities. Additionally, we used this planning grant period
to improve the proposal to include more innovative activities that were
incorporated into a new proposal submitted in December, 2015.



Broader Impacts: The STEM
Center improved recruitment, retention, and graduation rates of STEM students
by providing them with a rigorous research and mentoring program, and
specialized learning activities that translated to increased academic
performance and graduation rates. These activities increased the number of URM
students pursuing STEM degrees and attaining employment in STEM professions.
During the 2016-2017 academic year, the STEM data showed a significant increase
from the 2014-2015 academic year. The Center impacted an increased number of
students and faculty. This translated to increased retention and graduation
rates of STEM students. The number of STEM majors increased from 527 to 609,
the retention rate increased from 42% to 59% and the number of STEM graduates
increased from 96 to 138. Students and faculty regularly interacted through
planned activities, resulting in a more collegial atmosphere. More faculty
worked with students in research, mentoring, Journal Club, and special seminars
and workshops. Our students presented at four national meetings and one local
meeting. A total of 52 presentations were made by students and the number of
presentation awards was 23. The Center impacted a total of 352 students and
faculty participating in the various activities during the 2015-2017 academic
years. The evaluation results were positive and our participants indicated a
desire for more activities to be offered by the Center. The STEM Center
maintains a website linked to and from the UDC website.
